headline.main: NEW PLANS READY FOR SPACE STATION

results.snippet: The nine-year, $9 billion space-station program enters a crucial phase this week as the Clinton Administration ends a four-month bid to slim down the proposed outpost for orbiting astronauts while weighing full participation by the Russians.   The...
results.lead_paragraph: The nine-year, $9 billion space-station program enters a crucial phase this week as the Clinton Administration ends a four-month bid to slim down the proposed outpost for orbiting astronauts while weighing full participation by the Russians. The process of redesign, as full of zigs and zags as the beleaguered station program itself, has produced three alternatives, each progressively cheaper than the $31 billion, 350-foot design that the Clinton White House inherited from the Bush Administration.

headline.main: Top Graduates in Science Also Put Dreams on Hold

results.snippet: These are unsettling job-hunting times, even for the certifiably brilliant progeny of the nation's top schools in science and engineering.    Seniors who had their hearts set on creating the technologies of the next century are having trouble just...
results.lead_paragraph: These are unsettling job-hunting times, even for the certifiably brilliant progeny of the nation's top schools in science and engineering. Seniors who had their hearts set on creating the technologies of the next century are having trouble just lining up job interviews, and fresh new Ph.D.'s are settling for temporary teaching jobs offering little prospect of the security of tenure.

headline.main: PANEL URGES SHIFT IN STATION'S ORBIT

results.snippet: The expert panel advising the White House on redesigning the space-station has called for the proposed astronaut outpost to be launched into a "world orbit" where it could be reached not only by American space shuttles but also by Russian, Japanese...
results.lead_paragraph: The expert panel advising the White House on redesigning the space-station has called for the proposed astronaut outpost to be launched into a "world orbit" where it could be reached not only by American space shuttles but also by Russian, Japanese and Chinese rockets. The recommendation by the White House group for a different orbit is in a draft report to the White House that has not yet released. If kept in the final report and adopted by President Clinton, the shift would be a watershed in the history of the American space program.

results.snippet: Yanni  Gershwin Theater 222 West 51st Street Manhattan Through Sunday    When Yanni, the popular composer of New Age symphonic music, describes his esthetic philosophy, he likes to use space-age metaphors. Late in Tuesday's opening-night show, he...
results.lead_paragraph: Yanni Gershwin Theater 222 West 51st Street Manhattan Through Sunday When Yanni, the popular composer of New Age symphonic music, describes his esthetic philosophy, he likes to use space-age metaphors. Late in Tuesday's opening-night show, he told the story of an astronaut on the space shuttle who gazed down at the earth and noticed that the familiar borders separating European countries on maps were invisible. The lesson of the story, he declared, is that the divisions between people -- and by implication between musical genres -- are only "something in the mind."

headline.main: Donald Slayton Dies at 69; Was One of First Astronauts

results.snippet: Donald K. Slayton, one of the original seven American astronauts and an influential manager in the space agency, died yesterday at his home in League City, Tex., near the Johnson Space Center in suburban Houston. He was 69.  The cause of death was...
results.lead_paragraph: Donald K. Slayton, one of the original seven American astronauts and an influential manager in the space agency, died yesterday at his home in League City, Tex., near the Johnson Space Center in suburban Houston. He was 69. The cause of death was brain cancer, said Howard Benedict, executive director of the Mercury Seven Foundation.

results.lead_paragraph: Civil War Threat in Cambodia The leader of Cambodia's royalist party, a son of Prince Norodom Sihanouk, threatened war unless his half brother halts the secession movement he is leading. results.snippet: Some books are next to impossible to categorize.   Espionage plays a part in THE SILENCER, by the Glasgow-born Israeli author Simon Louvish (Interlink Books/Interlink Publishing, cloth, $24.95; paper, $10.95), and so do satire, humor, political...
results.lead_paragraph: Some books are next to impossible to categorize. Espionage plays a part in THE SILENCER, by the Glasgow-born Israeli author Simon Louvish (Interlink Books/Interlink Publishing, cloth, $24.95; paper, $10.95), and so do satire, humor, political analysis, Israeli-Arab relationships, the meaning of Jewishness, the terrors of religious fanaticism (Israeli as well as Arab), Realpolitik, Surrealism -- you name it.

results.snippet: The space shuttle Endeavour's astronauts spent much of the day trying to repair a water-recycling experiment, but their efforts were unsuccessful and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration finally told them to give up.   Flight directors...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Endeavour's astronauts spent much of the day trying to repair a water-recycling experiment, but their efforts were unsuccessful and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration finally told them to give up. Flight directors had considered adding an extra day beyond 7 A.M. Tuesday to the eight-day mission if the recycling experiment could be fixed.
